text: [Bob]: I saw Charlie head towards Medbay a few minutes ago; anyone else see him around?
[Erin]: Bob, you were in the cafeteria with Dave, Alice, and me, and you killed Dave right in front of us – why are you lying?
[Charlie]: Erin and I saw you kill Dave in the cafeteria, Bob, so vote him out!
[Alice]: Bob, stop lying – Erin and I both saw you kill Dave in the cafeteria, so everyone vote for Bob.
[Bob]: I was in the cafeteria pretending to empty the trash, and Charlie's suspiciously convenient accusation, matching Erin's, makes him a more likely suspect.
[Erin]: Bob, your deflection attempt is weak – Alice and I *both* saw you kill Dave, so vote Bob!
[Charlie]: Bob's desperate attempts to shift blame only confirm his guilt; vote Bob.
[Alice]: Bob's clearly trying to distract us with his lies about Charlie, so let's stick to the facts: he killed Dave in the cafeteria in front of Erin and me, so vote him out.
[Bob]: The coordinated accusations against me from Erin, Alice, and Charlie are suspiciously consistent, suggesting a possible alliance and a coordinated attempt to frame me.
[Erin]: Bob, trying to paint Alice, Charlie, and me as some kind of "coordinated alliance" is absurd – we're all just telling the truth: you killed Dave.
[Charlie]: Bob, your "coordinated alliance" theory is ridiculous – why would we coordinate to frame *you* when you killed Dave in front of multiple witnesses?
[Alice]: Bob, if we were framing you, why would we say we saw you kill Dave *in the cafeteria* where it would be easy to disprove if someone else had been there?

[Bob]: The suspiciously identical accounts from Alice, Erin, and Charlie lack specific details and seem rehearsed, suggesting a potential coordinated effort to frame me rather than an independent observation of a murder.

[Erin]: Bob, if our stories are "suspiciously identical," as you claim, then explain how three people could independently invent the *same lie*, with the same details, about you killing Dave in the cafeteria.
[Charlie]: Bob, if you were truly in the cafeteria emptying the trash, you should be able to tell us where the trash can is located and what kind of trash can it is.
[Alice]: Bob, describe the trash can in the cafeteria – what does it look like?
[Bob]: Their identical accounts lack specific details, suggesting a coordinated effort to frame me rather than an independent observation of a murder.
[Erin]: Bob, if you were emptying the trash can, what did you throw away?
[Charlie]: Bob, if Erin, Alice, and I were coordinating a lie, wouldn't we have come up with more convincing details than simply saying you killed Dave in the cafeteria?
[Alice]: Bob, if you were really emptying the trash, you'd be able to tell us what you saw in it – so what was in the trash can?
